**Write any decimal number (up to the thousands) in ordinary English words, using commas to separate the “thousand” and “hundred” groups, and putting the word “and” in front of the last two‑digit part.  
Rules to follow**

| Number | How to express it |
|--------|-------------------|
| 0‑9  | single word (zero, one, … nine) |
| 10‑19 | teen words |
| 20‑99 | tens word + (if units non‑zero) hyphen + unit word |
| 100‑999 | hundreds word + “and” + the two‑digit expression (as above). If the hundreds digit is zero, omit “hundred” entirely but still put “and” before the two‑digit part. |
| 1 000‑9 999 | thousands word + “, ” + the hundreds part (as above). Insert “and” before the two‑digit part of the hundreds group only when the hundreds digit is non‑zero; if the hundreds digit is zero, just write “and” before the two‑digit part after the comma. |

**Examples that show the rule**

* 4933 → “four thousand, nine hundred and thirty‑three”  
* 3674 → “three thousand, six hundred and seventy‑four”  
* 6747 → “six thousand, seven hundred and forty‑seven”  
* 6031 → “six thousand and thirty‑one” (hundreds digit is 0, so “hundred” is omitted, but “and” still precedes the two‑digit part)  
* 971 → “nine hundred and seventy‑one”  

So the instruction was: *“Translate an integer into written English, using commas after ‘thousand’ and putting ‘and’ before the tens–units part, obeying the conventions shown above.”*<|return|>
